comment:
Photo by @ismailferdous / A stop sign of Red 
					Rocks Park and Amphitheater, an open-air venue 
					carved from rock outside Denver, Colorado.

Photo by @babaktafreshi / It was September 1999, 
				   in a beautiful mountain village in Iran's Alamut Valley, 
				   where I set the camera to capture the nine-hour night on 
				   a single frame of Ektachrome 100 slide film. The Earth's 
				   rotation did the rest of the job, creating star trails, 
				   with Polaris, the North Star, at the top right.
				   I confess I had a more personal motivation: There was an 
				   amazing girl in our travel group with the same passion as me 
				   for the night sky. We were working together at an Iranian 
				   astronomy magazine and had just started dating. The long 
				   exposure gave me the whole night to chat with her under these 
				   poplar trees and the starry sky. We married two years later.

Photo by Daniella Zalcman @dzalcman / A wave crests in the
					North Sea just outside my berth. I spent September on an
					icebreaker ship in the Arctic, and it definitely took a few
					days of acclimating to the waves before I was able to function
					and work normally. Follow me at @dzalcman for more stories
					from the far north of our planet.
